risk.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the possibility that something bad, unpleasant, or dangerous may happen
risk.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Skiers always face the risk of serious injury.
There is a risk that the disease may spread further.
There is no risk to public health.
risk.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: an action that might have bad results
calculated risk (=a risk you take because you think a good result is quite likely)
risk.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: It was a risk, sending a letter to my house.
Isn’t he taking a bit of a risk in coming here?
I couldn’t take the risk of leaving him alone even for a short time.
take the risk of doing something
risk.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: something or someone that is likely to cause harm or danger
risk.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Meat from the infected animals is regarded as a serious health risk (=something likely to harm people’s health).
The tyre dump is a major fire risk (=something that could cause a dangerous fire).
She’s becoming a security risk (=someone who may tell important secrets to an enemy).
Polluted water supplies are a risk to public health.
risk.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a person or business judged according to the danger involved in giving them insurance or lending them money
risk.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Drivers under 21 are regarded as poor risks by insurance companies.
risk.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: Professional sport involves a relatively high risk of injury.
The risks of failure are quite low.
considerable
Starting up your own business involves considerable risks.
a big/great/huge risk
There is a great risk that the wound will become infected.
an increased/reduced risk
Those who smoke have an increased risk of heart disease.
a real risk
There is a real risk that there could be another war.
a serious/grave risk
The most serious risk of flooding this evening is on the River Wye.
a potential risk
The potential risks associated with this operation should not be ignored.
a financial risk
There is relatively little financial risk for the company.
a political risk
The political risks for the president are minimal.
attendant risks
Those who deal with firearms are generally aware of the attendant risks.
carry a risk
Most medical operations carry some risk.
pose a risk
Climate change poses serious risks to the environment.
involve/entail risk
Investments that provide a high return generally entail more risk.
reduce/minimize a risk
This diet could reduce your risk of certain cancers.
increase a risk
Smoking increases the risk of heart disease.
eliminate risk
You can’t eliminate risk in your life completely.
avoid a risk
They are anxious to avoid any risk of criticism.
face a risk
The dominant male faces the risk that adult males from the group will attack him.
risk + NOUN
a risk factor
High cholesterol is one of the risk factors associated with heart disease.
risk assessment
Engineering risk assessment is based on objective scientific criteria.
there is a risk
There is always a risk that mistakes will be made.
an element/degree of risk
There is always an element of risk in flying.
be worth the risk
Don’t walk home alone at night – it’s not worth the risk.
the risks involved/the risks associated with something
The soldiers were well aware of the risks involved.
The public are unwilling to accept the risks associated with nuclear energy.
the benefits outweigh the risks
The benefits to patients who are taking the drug far outweigh the risks.
risk.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to put something in a situation in which it could be lost, destroyed, or harmed
risk.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: When children start smoking, they don’t realize that they’re risking their health.
He risked his life helping others to escape.
I’m not going to risk my neck (=risk my life) just to save a common criminal.
Why risk life and limb (=risk your life and health) jumping out of a plane just to raise money for charity?
He’s prepared to risk everything to avoid this war.
You’d be crazy to risk your money on an investment like that!
risk.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to get into a situation where something unpleasant may happen to you
risk.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: He would prefer not to risk another embarrassing defeat.
Some people are prepared to risk imprisonment for what they believe.
Workers who broke the strike risked being attacked when they left the factory.
They may even risk losing their homes.
risk.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to do something that you know may have dangerous or unpleasant results
risk.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: She risked a glance back over her shoulder.
You could slip out of school between classes, but I wouldn’t risk it.
Are you prepared to risk traveling without an armed guard?
risk.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0]: Risk is followed by an -ing form, not an infinitive You say
They risk being shot if they are caught
risk.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the possibility that something may be lost, harmed, or damaged, or that something bad, unpleasant, or dangerous may happen
risk.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: If you’re considering starting a business, think carefully about the risks involved.
If your cheque book is lost or stolen, let your bank know immediately in order to reduce the risk of fraud on your account.
This is one high-technology venture that is fairly low in financial risk.
There is always a risk that the supplier will go out of business before the order is delivered.
risk.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: the possibility that the value of an asset may go up or down on the stockmarket
risk.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: There is always some risk with any kind of investment.
Fund managers have the resources and time to make judgments on which non-rated bonds are worth the risk.
risk.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: the possibility that a person or business will not pay back a loan
risk.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Many banks will not lend to high-risk borrowers.
risk.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: the possibility of a particular type of damage against which you are insured
risk.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Check in detail the risks that are covered by your policy.
risk.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: a person or business judged according to the risk involved in providing them with insurance or lending them money
risk.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: Drivers under 21 are regarded as poor risks by insurance companies.
People with previous heart attacks are considered to be higher insurance risks.
risk.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: to be in a situation where there is a risk of something bad happening to you
risk.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: If you fail to pay your bill, you run the risk of having your electricity supply cut off.
risk.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: to decide to do something even though you know it may have bad results
risk.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: The choice facing the Government is whether or not to take a risk with inflation by reducing interest rates.
risk.translation[2].definitions[7].defin: if something is at risk, it is in a situation where it may be damaged or lost
risk.translation[2].definitions[7].examp: We have to stop these rumours; the firm’s reputation is at risk.
Older workers are most at risk of experiencing long-term unemployment.
Your home is at risk  (=you might lose it) if you do not keep up repayments on the loan.
risk.translation[2].definitions[8].defin: if you do something at your own risk, you do it when you understand the possible dangers and have been warned about them
risk.translation[2].definitions[8].examp: All tours are undertaken at the visitor’s own risk.
risk.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to put something in a situation in which it could be lost, destroyed, or harmed
risk.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: You’d have to be crazy to risk your money on an investment like that!
They risked their financial future on a brand-new business venture.
risk.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to get into a situation where something unpleasant may happen to you
risk.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: The workers risked dismissal without compensation if the strike continued.
risk.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to do something that you know may have dangerous or unpleasant results
risk.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: No bank would risk giving them a loan.
